{{Multiple issues| {{no footnotes|date=March 2014}} {{advert|date=March 2014}} {{Orphan|date=March 2016}} }} {{Infobox organization | name = Centres de Recherche en Nutrition Humaine | image = Logo CRNHs.jpg | formation = since 1992 | location = France | purpose = Human Nutrition Clinical Research | leader_title = Director | leader_name = Pr Martine Laville (CRNH Rhône Alpes) | website = {{URL|www.crnh.fr}} }} The '''Centres de Recherche en Nutrition Humaine''' or '''CRNHs''' is a health research organisation based in [[France]]. Its goal is to improve the knowledge on the function properties of food, on metabolism and on human physiology, from basic research to the study of behaviours and their impact on health. The French territory is now provided with four CRNH having common tools and complementary scientific skills that allow them to develop multi center programs using their platforms and their specific skills. Nutritional issues are of major importance as populations around the world are considerably changing their diet and lifestyle with large health consequences. Food related-diseases such as [[obesity]], [[Diabetes insipidus|diabetes]], [[cardiovascular disease]]s, [[malnutrition]] and cancers are becoming major public health issues. CRNHs is the network of French research centres for human nutrition. CRNHs has the ambition to provide scientific answers to nutrition related health issues by promoting science and accelerating technology transfer to society. CRNHs aims to improve the knowledge on the functional properties of food and particularly its effects on metabolism and on human physiology by developing multi center programs using its platforms and its specific skills. CRNHs contributes to technology transfer between hospital sectors, research laboratories and industries. CRNHs’ expertise, its platforms for clinical exploration, analysis and data processing offer significant opportunities for collaborations. CRNHs develops research programs in nutrition within the framework of national, European and international research programs, working closely with industry partners and researchers worldwide. To advise on strategic development, CRNHs has been endowed with an external scientific advisory board composed of experts from several European. [[File:CRNHs map in France.PNG|thumb|[http://www.crnh.fr/ CRNHs map in France]]] == CRNHs missions == - Create a research pole of experts - Coordinate and lead multicentric research program to improve the knowledge in human nutrition - Create a platform between laboratories and hopitals for the translational research - Answer to public health major issues by giving a scientific answer to the nutrition problem == Organisation == Director : Pr Martine Laville (CRNH Rhône Alpes)
Co-directors : Pr Noel Cano (CRNH Auvergne), Alain Grynberg (CRNH Ile de France), Pr Michel Krempf (CRNH Ouest) In France there is now four CRNH having common tools and complementary scientific skills. [[File:Graph CRNHs.jpg|Graph CRNHs]] === CRNH Ouest === [[File:Logo CRNH Ouest.jpg|thumb|Logo CRNH Ouest]] Target tissues * Perinatal nutrition * Brain and enteric nervous system * Lipids and chronic diseases * Allergy === CRNH Auvergne === [[File:Logo CRNH Auvergne.jpg|thumb|Logo CRNH Auvergne]] Nutrition in elderly and in chronic diseases - Skeletal Muscle and Bone: sarcopenia and osteoporosis - Cardiovascular : prevention of metabolic syndrome and atherosclerosis, metabolomics, food metabolome - Gastro-intestinal: digestive pain, microbiota - Hormone-dependent cancer: nutrition, breast and prostate cancer === CRNH Ile de France === [[File:Logo CRNH Ile de France.jpg|thumb|Logo CRNH Ile de France]] Human dietary behaviour - Nutritional Epidemiology and cohorts, food economy - Adipose tissue - Cardiovascular - Gastro-intestinal - Endocrinology === CRNH Rhône Alpes === [[File:Logo CRNH Rhône-Alpes.jpg|thumb|Logo CRNH Rhône-Alpes]] Obesity, Diabetes, Physical Activity - Nutrition, health and well-being, - Clinical nutrition, aging and chronic diseases - Health properties of food and diet - Lipid/lipoprotein metabolism and cardio metabolic risks - Relationship between sedentary behaviour and health consequences ==See also== * [[:fr:CRNH|Centre de recherche en nutrition humaine Rhône-Alpes]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.crnh.fr/ CRNHs portal] * [http://www.clermont.inra.fr/crnh/ CRNH Auvergne] * [https://rhubarbe.uren.smbh.univ-paris13.fr/crnhidfv2/presentation.htm CRNH Île-de-France] * [https://www.crnh-nantes.fr/ CRNH Nantes ] * [http://www.crnh-rhone-alpes.fr/ CRNH Rhône-Alpes] [[Category:Nutrition]] [[Category:Medical and health organizations based in France]]

{{Unreferenced|date=December 2009}} The '''comedy of humours''' is a [[genre]] of [[drama]]tic [[comedy]] that focuses on a [[fictional character|character]] or range of characters, each of whom exhibits two or more overriding traits or '[[Humorism|humours]]' that dominates their personality, desires and conduct. This comic technique may be found in [[Aristophanes]], but the [[England|English]] [[playwright]]s [[Ben Jonson]] and [[George Chapman]] popularized the genre in the closing years of the sixteenth century. In the later half of the seventeenth century, it was combined with the [[comedy of manners]] in [[Restoration comedy]]. [[Image:Lavater1792.jpg|right|thumb|200px|The four '[[Humourism|humours]]' or temperaments (Clockwise from top right; [[choleric]]; [[Melancholia|melancholic]]; [[Four temperaments#Sanguine|sanguine]]; [[phlegmatic]]).]] In Jonson’s ''[[Every Man in His Humour]]'' (acted 1598), which made this type of [[Play (theatre)|play]] popular, all the words and acts of Kitely are controlled by an overpowering suspicion that his wife is unfaithful; George Downright, a country squire, must be "frank" above all things; the country gull in town determines his every decision by his desire to "catch on" to the manners of the city gallant. In his [[Induction (play)|Induction]] to ''[[Every Man out of His Humour]]'' (1599) Jonson explains his character-formula thus:
Some one peculiar quality
Doth so possess a man, that it doth draw
All his affects, his spirits, and his powers,
In their confluctions, all to run one way.
The comedy of humours owes something to earlier vernacular comedy but more to a desire to imitate the classical comedy of [[Plautus]] and [[Terence]] and to combat the vogue of [[Shakespearean comedy|romantic comedy]], as developed by [[William Shakespeare]]. The satiric purpose of the comedy of humours and its realistic method lead to more serious character studies with Jonson’s ''[[The Alchemist (play)|The Alchemist]]''. The humours each had been associated with physical and mental characteristics; the result was a system that was quite subtle in its capacity for describing types of personality. {{theatre-stub}} [[Category:Comedy]]

{{See also|Debt bondage}} [[File:Courtyard of the prison grounds.jpeg|thumb|The 18th century debtors' prison at the [[Castellania (Valletta)|Castellania]] in [[Valletta]], now the offices of the Health Ministry in [[Malta]]]] A '''debtors' prison''' is a [[prison]] for [[Natural person|people]] who are unable to pay [[debt]]. Through the mid 19th century, debtors' prisons (usually similar in form to locked [[workhouses]]) were a common way to deal with unpaid debt in places like [[Western Europe]].<ref name="Cory">Cory, Lucinda. [http://www.rib.uscourts.gov/ONTHEDOCKET/vol2,%20iss2.PDF "A Historical Perspective on Bankruptcy"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080228083132/http://www.rib.uscourts.gov/ONTHEDOCKET/vol2%2C%20iss2.PDF |date=February 28, 2008 }}, ''On the Docket'', Volume 2, Issue 2, U.S. Bankruptcy Court, District of Rhode Island, April/May/June 2000, retrieved December 20, 2007. </ref> Destitute persons who were unable to pay a court-ordered judgment would be incarcerated in these prisons until they had worked off their debt via labor or secured outside funds to pay the balance. The product of their labor went towards both the costs of their incarceration and their accrued debt. Increasing access and lenience throughout the [[history of bankruptcy law]] have made prison terms for unaggravated [[indigence]] illegal over most of the world.
Since the late 20th century, the term ''debtors' prison'' has also sometimes been applied by critics to [[criminal justice system]]s in which a court can sentence someone to prison over willfully unpaid [[Criminal procedure|criminal fees]], usually following the order of a [[judge]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.justanswer.com/topics-contempt-of-court/|title=What is Contempt of Court and other Contempt of Court Questions Answered|work=JustAnswer}}</ref> For example, in some jurisdictions within the [[United States]], people can be held in [[contempt of court]] and jailed after willful non-payment of [[Child support in the United States|child support]], garnishments, confiscations, fines, or back taxes. Additionally, though properly served [[Civil procedure|civil duties]] over private debts in nations such as the United States will merely result in a [[default judgement]] being rendered ''[[trial in absentia|in absentia]]'' if the defendant willfully declines to appear by law,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://nasonlawfirm.com/archives/548|title=What Happens If I Get Sued?|work=nasonlawfirm.com}}</ref> a substantial number of indigent debtors are legally incarcerated for the crime of failing to appear at civil debt proceedings as ordered by a judge. In this case, the crime is not indigence, but disobeying the judge's order to appear before the court.<ref name="nytimes1"/><ref name="tampa1"/><ref name="calpen1"/><ref name="minn1"/><ref name="harrington1"/> Critics argue that the "willful" terminology is subject to individual [[mens rea]] determination by a judge, rather than statute, and that since this presents the potential for judges to incarcerate legitimately indigent individuals, it amounts to a de facto "debtors' prison" system.
== History ==
=== Medieval Europe === During Europe's [[Middle Ages]], debtors, both men and women, were locked up together in a single, large cell until their families paid their debt.<ref>[http://www.articlesdepo.com/loans/56618.php Articlesdepo.com] {{dead link|date=May 2016|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}</ref> Debt prisoners often died of diseases contracted from other debt prisoners. Conditions included starvation and abuse from other prisoners. If the father of a family was imprisoned for debt, the family business often suffered while the mother and children fell into poverty. Unable to pay the debt, the father often remained in debtors' prison for many years. Some debt prisoners were released to become [[serf]]s or [[indentured servant]]s ([[debt bondage]]) until they paid off their debt in labor.
== By region ==
=== Canada === {{main|Imprisonment for debt (Upper Canada)}}
=== Council of Europe === Article 1 of [[European Convention on Human Rights#Protocol 4 - civil imprisonment, free movement, expulsion|Protocol 4]] of the [[European Convention on Human Rights]] prohibits the imprisonment of people for breach of a contract. Turkey and the United Kingdom (due to concerns over British nationality law) have signed but never ratified Protocol 4. Greece and Switzerland have neither signed nor ratified this protocol.
=== France ===
France allows for ''contrainte par corps'', now denominated ''contrainte judiciaire'', for money owed to the State by non-insolvant debtors aged from 18 to 65; its length is limited following the amount of the debt and aims to pressure the debtor to pay his debts, consequently the owed money stays owed to the State.
=== Germany === [[File:Nuernberg-maennereisen-v-nw.jpg|thumb|right|Schuldturm in [[Nuremberg]]]] In the late Middle Ages, and at the beginning of the modern era, public law was codified in Germany. This served to standardize the coercive arrest (''Pressionshaft''), and got rid of the many arbitrary sanctions that were not universal.<ref>[http://www.berlinonline.de/berliner-zeitung/archiv/.bin/dump.fcgi/2006/0919/recht/0108/index.html Berlinonline.de] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101222215014/http://www.berlinonline.de/berliner-zeitung/archiv/.bin/dump.fcgi/2006/0919/recht/0108/index.html |date=December 22, 2010 }}</ref> In some areas (like Nürnberg) the debtor could sell or redistribute their debt.
In most of the cities, the towers and city fortifications functioned as jails. For certain sanctions there were designated prisons, hence some towers being called debtors' prison (''Schuldturm''). The term ''Schuldturm'', outside of the Saxon constitution, became the catchword for public law debtor’s prison.
In the early modern era, the debtor’s detainment or citizen’s arrest remained valid in Germany. Sometimes it was used as a tool to compel payment, other times it was used to secure the arrest of an individual and ensure a trial against them in order to garnish wages, [[replevin]] or a form of [[trover]]. This practice was particularly disgraceful to a person’s identity, but had different rules than criminal trials. It was more similar to the modern enforcement of sentences (''Strafvollzug'') e.g. the debtor would be able to work off their debt for a certain amount of days, graduated by how much they owed.
The [[North German Confederation]] eliminated debtors' prisons on May 29, 1868.
At present a comparable concept to debtors' prison still exists in various forms in Germany:{{fact|date=July 2017}} * A maximum of 6 weeks coercive arrest for failure to pay fine (''Bußgeld''). * A maximum of 6 months coercive arrest for failure to issue an oath of not being able to pay any kind of liability. * As an alternative sentence, if a fine (''Geldstrafe'') is not paid, up to 6 months. * As a personal arrest for the securing of a foreclosure or garnishment on wages. * Failure to pay child support as ordered by court, which is a crime under the Penal Code.
=== Great Britain (later the United Kingdom) === [[File:St Briavels Castle Debtors Prison.jpg|thumb|right|A mid-Victorian depiction of the debtors' prison at [[St Briavels Castle]]]] In England during the eighteenth and nineteenth centuries, 10,000 people were imprisoned for debt each year.<ref>{{Cite journal|url = |title = A 20th Century Debate About Imprisonment for Debt|last = Ware|first = Stephen|date = July 2014|journal = American Journal of Legal History|doi = |pmid = |access-date = }}</ref> A prison term did not alleviate a person's debt, however; an inmate was typically required to repay the creditor in-full before being released.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.historyextra.com/facts/nutshell-debtors’-prisons|title = In a Nutshell: Debtor's Prisons|date = February 10, 2015|accessdate = |website = History Extra|publisher = BBC|last = Wilkes|first = Jonny|deadurl = yes|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20151212102229/http://www.historyextra.com/facts/nutshell-debtors%E2%80%99-prisons|archivedate = December 12, 2015|df = }}</ref> In the [[Kingdom of Great Britain]] and the later [[United Kingdom]], debtors' prisons varied in the amount of freedom they allowed the debtor. With a little money, a debtor could pay for some freedoms; some prisons allowed inmates to conduct business and to receive visitors; others (including the [[Fleet Prison|Fleet]] and [[King's Bench Prison]]s) even allowed inmates to live a short distance outside the prison—a practice known as the 'Liberty of the Rules'—and the Fleet even tolerated clandestine '[[Fleet Marriage]]s'.
Life in these prisons, however, was far from pleasant, and the inmates were forced to pay for their keep. Samuel Byrom, son of the writer and poet [[John Byrom]], was imprisoned for debt in the Fleet in 1725, and in 1729 he sent a petition to his old school friend, the [[Lionel Sackville, 1st Duke of Dorset|Duke of Dorset]], in which he raged against the injustices of the system. Some debtor prisoners were even less fortunate, being sent to prisons with a mixture of vicious criminals and petty criminals, and many more were confined to a single cell.
The father of the [[England|English]] author [[Charles Dickens]] was sent to one of these prisons (the [[Marshalsea Prison|Marshalsea]]), which were often described in Dickens's novels.<ref>[http://www.charles-dickens.com/ Charles Dickens Bibliography] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101215121741/http://www.charles-dickens.com/ |date=2010-12-15 }} at charles-dickens.com</ref> He became an advocate for debt prison reform, and his novel ''[[Little Dorrit]]'' dealt directly with this issue.<ref>{{Cite journal|url = |title = Charles Dickens, Social Worker in His Time|last = Andrews|first = Arlene B.|date = October 2012|journal = Social Work|doi = |pmid = |access-date = }}</ref>
The [[Debtors' Act of 1869]] limited the ability of the courts to sentence debtors to prison, but it did not entirely prohibit them from doing so. Debtors who had the means to pay their debt, but did not do so, could still be incarcerated for up to six weeks, as could those who defaulted on debts to the court.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.legislation.gov.uk/ukpga/Vict/32-33/62/part/I|title = Debtors Act of 1869|date = |accessdate = 6 December 2015|website = |publisher = The National Archives (UK)|last = |first = }}</ref> Initially, there was a significant reduction in the number of debtors imprisoned following the passage of the 1869 Act. By 1870, the total number of debtors imprisoned decreased by almost 2,000, dropping from 9,759 in 1869 to 6,605 in 1870.<ref name=":0">{{Cite book|title = Judicial Statistics, England and Wales, Part 2|last = |first = |publisher = Great Britain Home Office|year = 1907|isbn = |location = |pages = 35|url = https://books.google.com/?id=64AzAQAAMAAJ&lpg=PA33&dq=debt%20imprisonment%20statistics%20england&pg=PA33#v=onepage&q=debt%20imprisonment%20statistics%20england&f=false}}</ref> However, by 1905 that number had increased to 11,427.<ref name=":0" />
Some of London's debtors' prisons were the [[Coldbath Fields Prison]], [[Fleet Prison]], [[Giltspur Street Compter]], [[King's Bench Prison]], [[Marshalsea Prison]], [[Poultry Compter]], and [[Wood Street Counter]]. The most famous was [[The Clink|the Clink prison]], which had a debtor's entrance in Stoney Street. This prison gave rise to the British slang term for being incarcerated in any prison, hence "in the clink". Its location also gave rise to the term for being financially embarrassed, "stoney broke".
=== Greece === Ιmprisonment for debts, whether to the tax office or to a private bank, was still practiced until January 2008, when the law changed after imprisonment for unpaid taxes, as well as other debts to the government or to the social security office, was declared unconstitutional after having been practiced for 173 years; imprisonment was, however, still retained for debts to private banks.{{clarify|date=April 2009}} The situation regarding imprisonment (προσωποκράτηση (prosōpokrάtēsē): custody) for debts to the government is still unclear, as courts continue to have this ability for criminal acts.<ref>[http://www.reporto.gr/news.asp?ID=7710 Reporto.gr] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090205184819/http://www.reporto.gr/news.asp?ID=7710 |date=February 5, 2009 }}</ref>
===Malta=== {{main|Castellania (Valletta)}} An eighteenth century debtors' prison is found within the [[Castellania (Valletta)|Castellania]] in [[Valletta]], Malta, now used as offices by the Ministry for Health. It remained in use as a prison until the nineteenth century. People who fail to pay their debts today are given prison sentences to be served at Corradino Prison in [[Paola, Malta|Paola]].
=== United Arab Emirates === Debtors in the [[United Arab Emirates]], including [[Dubai]], are imprisoned for failing to pay their debts. This is a common practice in the country. Banks are not sympathetic to the debtors once they are in prison, so many just choose to leave the country where they can negotiate for settlements later. The practice of fleeing UAE to avoid arrest because of debt defaults is considered a viable option to customers who are unable to meet their obligations.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2009/02/12/world/middleeast/12dubai.html|work=The New York Times|title=Laid-Off Foreigners Flee as Dubai Spirals Down|first=Robert F.|last=Worth|date=2009-02-12|accessdate=2010-05-01}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.thenational.ae/business/how-the-world-is-dealing-with-the-issue-of-debtors|work=The National|title=How the world is dealing with the issue of debtors|first=Wayne|last=Arnold|date=2008-12-24|accessdate=2010-05-15}}</ref>
=== United States of America ===
==== Early debtors' prisons (colonization–1850) ==== Many Colonial American jurisdictions established debtors' prisons using the same models used in Great Britain. [[James Wilson]], a signatory to the [[United States Declaration of Independence|Declaration of Independence]], spent some time in a debtors' prison while still serving as an [[Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States|Associate Justice]] of the U.S. Supreme Court.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.ushistory.org/declaration/signers/wilson.htm |publisher=ushistory.org |location= |title=James Wilson 1742-1798 |first=Thomas |last=Kindig |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150710163946/http://www.ushistory.org/Declaration/Signers/wilson.htm |archivedate=2015-07-10 |df= }}</ref> Fellow signatory [[Robert Morris (financier)|Robert Morris]] spent three years, from 1798 to 1801, in the Prune Street Debtors' Prison, [[Philadelphia]]<ref>{{cite book|last=Axelrod|first=Alan|title=The Real History of the American Revolution|date=2007|page=349}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.ushistory.org/tour/washington-square.htm|publisher=ushistory.org|title=Washington Square: Go to Jail}}</ref> Henry Lee III, better known as [[Henry Lee III|Henry "Light-Horse" Lee]], a [[American Revolutionary War|Revolutionary War]] general and father of Robert E. Lee, was imprisoned for debt between 1808 and 1809<ref>{{cite news|url=http://leearchive.wlu.edu/faqs/members.html|work=Washington and Lee University|location=United States|title=Was LHHL a good businessman?|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121101233543/http://leearchive.wlu.edu/faqs/members.html|archivedate=2012-11-01|df=}}</ref> where he made use of his time by writing "Memoirs of the War".<ref>{{cite news|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=SIEfAAAAYAAJ|work=google.books|location=United States|title=Memoirs of the war in the southern department of the United States|year=1812|first=Henry|last=Lee III}}</ref>
Debtors' prisons were prevalent throughout the [[United States]] up until the mid-1800s. Economic hardships following the [[War of 1812]] with [[Great Britain]] helped swell prison populations with simple debtors. This resulted in significant attention being given to plights of the poor and most dependent jailed under the widespread practice, possibly for the first time.<ref>{{cite book|title=The Acquisition of Political, Social, and Industrial Rights of Man in America|last=McMaster|first=John B.|year=1903|publisher=Imperial Press|location=Cleveland|isbn=978-1-4097-7187-6|pages=63–66|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=B2cUAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA63&lpg=PA63&dq=1816+debtors+prison#v=onepage&q=1816%20debtors%20prison&f=false|accessdate=2010-05-16}}</ref> Increasing disfavor over debtors' prisons along with the advent and early development of [[Bankruptcy in the United States|U.S. bankruptcy laws]] led states to begin restricting imprisonment for most civil debts.<ref>{{cite journal|author=G. Stanley Joslin|title=Bankruptcy: Anglo-American Contrasts|journal=Modern Law Review|volume=29|issue=2|pages=149–59|date=January 1966|doi=10.1111/j.1468-2230.1966.tb01111.x}}</ref> At that time growing use of the [[poorhouse]]<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.poorhousestory.com/history.htm|work=Poor House History|location=United States|title=History of the 19th century American poorhouses}}</ref> and poor farm were also seen as institutional alternatives for debtors' prisons. The United States ostensibly eliminated the imprisonment of debtors under federal law in 1833<ref name="brennan">{{cite news|url=http://www.aclu-wa.org/news/aclu-report-exposes-modern-day-debtors-prisons|work=The Brennan Center for Justice|location=[http://www.aclu-wa.org/sites/default/files/attachments/Criminal_Justice_Debt_report_V8.pdf "The Hidden Costs of Criminal Justice Debt" The Brennan Report.PDF]|title=The Brennan Report .pdf Source Page|date=October 2010|first=Alicia Bannon, Mitali Nagrecha|last=Rebekah Diller}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.independent.org/newsroom/article.asp?id=2229|work=The Independent Institute|location=United States|title=The Return of Debtors' Prison?|date=1 April 2008|first=Wendy|last=McElroy}}</ref> leaving the practice of debtors' prisons to states. :''Changes to state debtors' prisons'' ::[[Kentucky]] 1821 – save where fraud was shown or suspected ::[[Ohio]] 1828 ::[[Maryland]] 1830 – for debts under $30 ::[[New Jersey]] 1830 ::[[Vermont]] 1830 ::[[Massachusetts]] 1831 – exempted females for any amount and males with debts under $10 ::[[New York (state)|New York]] 1832, [[Connecticut]] 1837, [[Louisiana]] 1840, [[Missouri]] 1845, [[Alabama]] 1848, [[Virginia]] 1849
===== Historic preservation ===== * [[Debtors' Prison (Accomac, Virginia)|Accomac]], Virginia – constructed 1782–1783, converted to a "gaol [jail] for debtors" in 1824, closed 1849<ref>{{cite news|url=http://preservationvirginia.org/visit/historic-properties/accomac-debtors-prison|work=APVA|location=Preservation Society Virginia|title=Accomac Debtor’s Prison|year=2012|access-date=2012-10-18|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120930013615/http://preservationvirginia.org/visit/historic-properties/accomac-debtors-prison|archive-date=2012-09-30|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref> * [[Debtors' Prison (Tappahannock, Virginia)|Tappahannock]], Virginia – constructed prior to 1769, converted to other uses 1849<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.tappahannock.us/prison.htm|work=Essex County Virginia|location=Tappahannock.us|title=Historical walking tour of Tappahannock|year=2012}}</ref> * [[Debtors' Prison (Worsham, Virginia)|Worsham]], Virginia – authorized 1786, constructed as a "goal [jail] for debtors" 1787, closed sometime between 1820 and 1849<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.nationalregisterofhistoricplaces.com/va/Prince+Edward/state.html|work=National Register of Historical Places|location=Worsham, Prince Edward County|title=Debtor's Prison (added 1972 #72001412), Worsham|year=2012}}</ref>
==== Modern debtors' prisons (1970–current) ==== {{anchor|Modern_Debtors.27_Prison}} {{anchor|Modern_debtors.27_prisons_.281970_.E2.80.93_current.29}} While the United States no longer has brick and mortar debtors' prisons, or "gaols for debtors" of private debts, the term "debtor's prison" in modern times sometimes refers to the practice of imprisoning indigent criminal defendants for matters related to either a fine or a fee imposed in criminal judgments.<ref name="harrington1">{{cite news|url=https://www.scribd.com/doc/100075454/Judge-Hub-Harrington-Order-to-Harpersville|work=Scribd Research Law|location=[http://media.al.com/spotnews/other/Judge%20Hub%20Harrington%20order%20to%20Harpersville.pdf Shelby County, Harpersville .pdf] Alabama, USA|title=Circuit Court of Shelby County CV 2010-900183.00|date=July 2012|first=Shelby County|last=Circuit Court}}</ref><ref name="think1">{{cite news|url=http://thinkprogress.org/justice/2011/12/13/388303/the-return-of-debtors-prisons-thousands-of-americans-jailed-for-not-paying-their-bills/|work=Think Progress|location=United States|title=The Return Of Debtor's Prisons|date=13 December 2011|first=Marie|last=Diamond}}</ref> To what extent a debtor will actually be prosecuted varies from state to state.<ref name="nytimes1">{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2009/04/06/opinion/06mon4.html|work=The New York Times|location=United States|title=The New Debtors’ Prisons|date=5 April 2009|first=Editorial|last=Writer}}</ref> This modern use of the term debtors' prison arguably has its start with precedent rulings in 1970, 1971 and 1983 by the U.S. Supreme Court,<ref name="tampa1">{{cite news|url=http://www.tampabay.com/opinion/editorials/article991963.ece|work=The Tampa Bay Times|location=United States|title=Debtors' prison - again|date=14 April 2009|first=Staff|last=Writer|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100706150424/http://www.tampabay.com/opinion/editorials/article991963.ece|archivedate=6 July 2010|df=}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.aclu-wa.org/news/aclu-report-exposes-modern-day-debtors-prisons|work=ACLU, USA| location=[http://www.aclu-wa.org/sites/default/files/attachments/InForAPenny_web.pdf "In for a Penny" ACLU Report.PDF]|title=ACLU Report .pdf Source Page|date=October 2010|first=U.S.|last=American Civil Liberties Union}}</ref> and passage of the [[Bankruptcy Reform Act of 1978|Bankruptcy Reform Act]] of 1978.
In 1970, the Court ruled in ''[[List of United States Supreme Court cases, volume 399|Williams v. Illinois]]'' that extending a maximum prison term because a person is too poor to pay fines or court costs violates the right to equal protection under the [[Fourteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution|Fourteenth Amendment]].<ref>{{cite journal|url=https://scholar.google.com/scholar_case?case=8107436400939860073|location=United States|title=Williams v. Illinois, 399 U.S. 235 (1970)|date=29 June 1970|author=Supreme Court of the United States}}</ref> During 1971 in [[List of United States Supreme Court cases, volume 401|Tate v. Short]], the Court found it unconstitutional to impose a fine as a sentence and then automatically convert it into "a jail term solely because the defendant is indigent and cannot forthwith pay the fine in full."<ref>{{cite journal|url=https://scholar.google.com/scholar_case?case=13903398873753836115|location=United States|title=Tate v. Short, 401 U.S. 395 (1971)|date=2 March 1971|author=Supreme Court of the United States}}</ref> And in the 1983 ruling for ''[[List of United States Supreme Court cases, volume 461|Bearden v. Georgia]],'' the Court ruled that the Fourteenth Amendment bars courts from revoking probation for a failure to pay a fine without first inquiring into a person's ability to pay and considering whether there are adequate alternatives to imprisonment.<ref>{{cite journal|url=https://scholar.google.com/scholar_case?case=12397530380886309714|location=United States|title=Bearden v. Georgia, 461 U.S. 660 (1983)|date=24 May 1983|first=Supreme Court of|last=United States}}</ref>
A year-long study released in 2010 of fifteen [[List of U.S. states by incarceration rate|states with the highest prison populations]]<ref>{{cite news|title=Alabama • Arizona • California • Florida • Georgia • Louisiana • Illinois • Michigan • Missouri • New York • North Carolina • Ohio • Pennsylvania • Texas • Virginia|year=2010}}</ref> by the [[Brennan Center for Justice]], found that all fifteen states sampled have jurisdictions that arrest people for failing to pay debt or appear at debt related hearings.<ref name="brennan"/> The study identified four causes that lead to debtors' prison type arrests for debts: * State laws that attempt to make criminal justice debt a condition of probation, parole, or other correctional supervision with failure to pay resulting in arrest and reimprisonment.<ref name="oklahoma1">{{cite news|url=http://www.oscn.net/applications/oscn/DeliverDocument.asp?CiteID=84821|work=State Court Network|location=Oklahoma, United States|title=Section Article 2 section 13 - Imprisonment for debt (2 § 13)|year=2012|first=State of|last=Oklahoma}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://seattletimes.com/html/localnews/2013066985_debtor04m.html|work=The Seattle Times|location=Washington, USA|title=Unpaid court costs can bring cycle of debt, threat of jail, ACLU warns|date=3 October 2010|first=Susan|last=Kelleher}}</ref> * State laws that consider imprisonment as a penalty for failure to pay criminal justice debt. These actions are considered a civil contempt of court charge, thus technically not in violation of state constitutions that prohibit debtors' prisons, but for the same reason those incarcerated must be released immediately if they either pay or prove themselves unable to do so.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.aclu-wa.org/news/aclu-report-exposes-modern-day-debtors-prisons|work=ACLU of WA|location=United States|title=ACLU Report Exposes Modern-Day Debtors' Prisons|year=2010|first=Staff|last=Writer}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.startribune.com/investigators/95693219.html|work=The Star Tribune|location=MN, United States|title=Is jailing debtors the same as debtors jail?|date=17 March 2011|first=Chris|last=Serres|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121017111152/http://www.startribune.com/investigators/95693219.html|archivedate=17 October 2012|df=}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.kctv5.com/story/15894440/kctv5-investigations-modern-debtors-prisons|work=CBS, KCTV5 News|location=Kansas City, USA|title=Modern Debtors' Prison|date=1 June 2012|first=DeAnn Smith|last=Stacey Cameron|access-date=2012-10-21|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120705170608/http://www.kctv5.com/story/15894440/kctv5-investigations-modern-debtors-prisons|archive-date=2012-07-05|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref> * Citizens choosing jail time under state programs where imprisonment is a way of paying down court imposed debt.<ref name="calpen1">{{cite news|url=http://codes.lp.findlaw.com/cacode/PEN/3/2/8/1/s1205|work=Find Law.com|location=California Penal Code|title=CAL. PEN. CODE § 1205|year=2012|first=State of|last=California}}</ref><ref name="morev1">{{cite news|url=http://law.justia.com/codes/missouri/2011/titlexxxvii/chapter543/section543270/|work=Justia US Law.com|location=2011 Missouri Revised Statutes|title=MO Rev Stat § 543.270|year=2011|first=State of|last=Missouri}}</ref> * States that regularly arrest citizens for criminal justice debt prior to appearing at debt-related hearings, leading in many cases to multi-day jail terms pending an ability to pay hearing.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.npr.org/2011/12/12/143274773/unpaid-bills-land-some-debtors-behind-bars|work=NPR News, WBEZ|location=United States|title=Unpaid Bills Land Some Debtors Behind Bars|date=20 April 2012|first=Susan|last=An}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://rockrivertimes.com/2012/05/31/illinois-attorney-general-supports-bill-to-keep-debtors-from-being-sent-to-prison/|work=The Rock River Times|location=Illinois, USA|title=Illinois Attorney General supports bill to keep debtors from being sent to prison|date=30 May 2012|first=Staff|last=Writer|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121011062153/http://rockrivertimes.com/2012/05/31/illinois-attorney-general-supports-bill-to-keep-debtors-from-being-sent-to-prison/|archivedate=11 October 2012|df=}}</ref> * The routine jailing of persons who owe civil debt when such debts are related to child support arrears. Imprisonment for such debt is legally justified by the legal fiction that the incarceration is not for the debt, but rather for not obeying a court order to pay the debt.
In an article in ''[[The American Conservative]]'', Michael Shindler argues that another factor responsible for debtors' prison type arrests is that "Whereas indigent defendants have a Sixth Amendment right to a court-appointed lawyer in criminal cases involving incarceration, indigent debtors in state and local courts have no one to defend them against the error and abuse that characterizes debt collection litigation." Similarly, Shindler writes, regarding explicitly illegal debtors' prison type arrests ordered by local judges,"the reason these officials engage in this sort of excessive behavior is often due to ignorance."<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Shindler|first=Michael|date=September 17, 2018|title=Private Creditors Can Put You in Jail|url=https://www.theamericanconservative.com/articles/the-travesty-of-private-creditors-putting-people-in-jail/|journal=The American Conservative|volume=|pages=|via=}}</ref>
==== Modern examples ==== In 2014, [[National Public Radio]] (NPR) posted a report stating that there were still cases of judges imprisoning people who have not paid court fees.<ref>Shapiro, Joseph. "[https://www.npr.org/2014/05/21/313118629/supreme-court-ruling-not-enough-to-prevent-debtors-prisons Supreme Court Ruling Not Enough To Prevent Debtors Prisons]" ([https://www.webcitation.org/6QhZXk2U1?url=http://www.npr.org/2014/05/21/313118629/supreme-court-ruling-not-enough-to-prevent-debtors-prisons Archive]). [[National Public Radio]]. May 21, 2014. Retrieved on June 30, 2014.</ref> The [[American Civil Liberties Union]] has been challenging such policies since 2009.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.aclu.org/issues/racial-justice/race-and-criminal-justice/debtors-prisons|accessdate=2015-05-08|title=Debtors' Prisons}}</ref>
In September, 2015, the town of [[Bowdon, Georgia]] made international news<ref>{{cite web|last1=Pleasance|first1=Chris|title=Shocking court video emerges showing Georgia judge threatening to jail defendants if they cannot pay minor fines|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-3224298/Shocking-court-video-emerges-showing-Georgia-judge-threatening-jail-defendants-pay-minor-fines.html|website=Daily Mail|publisher=Daily Mail.com|accessdate=19 November 2015|date=2015-09-06}}</ref> when a sitting municipal judge, Robert A. Diment, was surreptitiously recorded threatening defendants with jail time for traffic violations if they did not provide immediate payment.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Dewan|first1=Shaila|title=A Surreptitious Courtroom Video Prompts Changes in a Georgia Town|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/09/05/us/a-surreptitious-courtroom-video-prompts-changes-in-a-georgia-town.html|newspaper=The New York Times|accessdate=19 November 2015|date=2015-09-04}}</ref> The incidents caused the Bowdon Municipal Court to be closed for a month in order to implement changes in policy.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Miller|first1=Brittany|title=Court closes after judge tells defendant they can't leave until traffic fines are paid |url=http://www.cbs46.com/story/29995054/judge-pay-the-traffic-fine-or-go-to-jail|website=CBS46.com|publisher=CBS News|accessdate=19 November 2015}}</ref>

== International agreements == In 1976 Article 11 of the ICCPR – [[International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights]] – came into effect stating, "No one shall be imprisoned merely on the ground of inability to fulfill a contractual obligation."
This international treaty contradicts many domestic laws of ratified states which allows for civil jail.

revision.text:
The '''decline effect''' may occur when scientific claims receive decreasing support over time. The term was first described by parapsychologist [[Joseph Banks Rhine]] in the 1930s to describe the disappearing of [[extrasensory perception]] (ESP) of psychic experiments conducted by Rhine over the course of study or time. In its more general term, Cronbach, in his review article of science "Beyond the two disciplines of scientific psychology" referred to the phenomenon as "generalizations decay."<ref>{{Cite journal | doi = 10.1037/h0076829| title = Beyond the two disciplines of scientific psychology| journal = American Psychologist| volume = 30| issue = 2| pages = 116–127| year = 1975| last1 = Cronbach | first1 = L. J. }}</ref> The term was once again used in a 2010 article by [[Jonah Lehrer]] published in ''[[The New Yorker]]''.<ref name="Lehrer">{{Cite web | author = Jonah_Lehrer | title = The Truth Wears Off | url = http://www.newyorker.com/reporting/2010/12/13/101213fa_fact_lehrer | publisher = The New Yorker | year = 2010}}</ref>
==Examples==
In his article, Lehrer gives several examples where the decline effect is allegedly showing. In the first example, the development of second generation anti-psychotic drugs, reveals that the first tests had demonstrated a dramatic decrease in the subjects' psychiatric symptoms.<ref name="Lehrer" /> However, after repeating tests this effect declined and in the end it was not possible to document that these drugs had any better effect than the first generation anti-psychotics.
A well-known example of the decline effect can be seen in early experiments conducted by Professor [[Jonathan Schooler]] examining the effects of verbalization on non-verbal cognition. In an initial series of studies Schooler found evidence that verbal rehearsal of previously seen faces or colors markedly impaired subsequent recognition.<ref>{{Cite journal | pmid = 2295225 | year = 1990 | author1 = Schooler | first1 = J. W. | title = Verbal overshadowing of visual memories: Some things are better left unsaid | journal = Cognitive Psychology | volume = 22 | issue = 1 | pages = 36–71 | last2 = Engstler-Schooler | first2 = T. Y. | doi=10.1016/0010-0285(90)90003-m }}</ref> This phenomenon is referred to as ''[[verbal overshadowing]]''. Although verbal overshadowing effects have been repeatedly observed by Schooler, as well as other researchers, they have also proven to be somewhat challenging to replicate.<ref name="Lehrer" /><ref>{{cite journal |last=Chin |first=J. M. |last2=Schooler |first2=J. W. |year=2009 |title=Why do words hurt? content, process, and criterion shift accounts of verbal overshadowing |journal=European Journal of Cognitive Psychology |volume=20 |issue=3 |pages=396–413 |doi=10.1080/09541440701728623 }}</ref><ref name=schooler>{{Cite journal | pmid = 21350443 | year = 2011 | author1 = Schooler | first1 = J | title = Unpublished results hide the decline effect | journal = Nature | volume = 470 | issue = 7335 | pages = 437 | doi = 10.1038/470437a }}</ref> Verbal overshadowing effects in a variety of domains were initially easy to find, but then became increasingly difficult to replicate indicating a decline effect in the phenomenon. Schooler has now become one of the more prominent researchers examining the decline effect. He has argued that addressing the decline effect may require a major revision to the scientific process whereby scientists log their protocols before conducting their research and then, regardless of outcome, report their findings in an open access repository (such as Brain Nosek's "Project Implicit").<ref>http://projectimplicit.net/nosek/</ref> Schooler is currently working with the Fetzer Foundation to organize a major meeting of scientists from various disciplines to consider alternative accounts of the decline effect and approaches for rigorously addressing it.<ref>{{Cite journal | doi = 10.1080/1047840X.2012.705246| title = Modernizing Science: Comments on Nosek and Bar-Anan (2012)| journal = Psychological Inquiry| volume = 23| issue = 3| pages = 281–284| year = 2012| last1 = Mooneyham | first1 = B. W. | last2 = Franklin | first2 = M. S. | last3 = Mrazek | first3 = M. D. | last4 = Schooler | first4 = J. W. }}</ref>
In 1991, Danish zoologist Anders Møller discovered a connection between symmetry and sexual preference of female birds in nature. This sparked a huge interest in the topic and a lot of follow-up research was published. In three years following the original discovery, 90% of studies confirmed Møller's hypothesis. However, the same outcome was published in just four out of eight research papers in 1995, and only a third in next three years.<ref name="Lehrer2">{{Cite news | author = Jonah Lehrer | title = The Mysterious Decline Effect | url = https://www.wired.com/wiredscience/2010/12/the-mysterious-decline-effect | publisher = Wired | date=2010-12-09}}</ref>
==Explanations==
One of the explanations of the effect is [[regression to the mean|regression toward the mean]] (this is a statistical phenomenon happening when a variable is extreme on the first experiments and by later experiments tend to regress towards average), although this does not explain why sequential results decline in a linear fashion, rather than fluctuating about the true mean as would be expected.<ref name=schooler/>
Another reason may be the [[publication bias]]: scientists and scientific journals prefer to publish positive results of experiments and tests over null results, especially with new ideas.<ref name="Lehrer" /> As a result, the journals may refuse to publish papers that do not prove that the idea works. Later, when an idea is accepted, journals may refuse to publish papers that support it.
In the debate that followed the original article, Lehrer answered some of the questions by claiming that scientific observations might be shaped by one's expectations and desires, sometimes even unconsciously, thus creating a bias towards the desired outcome.<ref name="Lehrer2" />
A significant factor contributing to the decline effect can also be the sample size of the scientific research, since smaller sample size is very likely to give more extreme results, suggesting a significant breakthrough, but also a higher probability of an error. Typical examples of this effect are the opinion polls, where those including a larger number of people are closer to reality than those with a small pool of respondents.<ref>{{Cite web | author = John Allen Paulos | authorlink = John Allen Paulos | title = The decline effect and why scientific 'Truth' so often turns out wrong | url = http://abcnews.go.com/Technology/WhosCounting/decline-effect-scientific-truth-turns-wrong/story?id=12510202 | publisher = ABC News | year = 2010}}</ref> This suggestion would not appear to account for the observed decrease over time regardless of sample size. Researcher [[John Ioannidis]] offers some explanation. He states that early research is usually small and more prone to highly positive results supporting the original idea, including early confirmatory studies. Later, as larger studies are being made, they often show regression to the mean and a failure to repeat the early exaggerated results.<ref>{{Cite journal | last1 = Ioannidis | first1 = J. P. A. | authorlink1 = John P. A. Ioannidis| title = Why Most Published Research Findings Are False | journal = PLoS Medicine | volume = 2 | issue = 8 | pages = e124 | year = 2005 | pmid = 16060722 | pmc = 1182327 | doi = 10.1371/journal.pmed.0020124}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal | last1 = Ioannidis | first1 = J. P. A. | title = Contradicted and Initially Stronger Effects in Highly Cited Clinical Research | doi = 10.1001/jama.294.2.218 | journal = JAMA: the Journal of the American Medical Association | volume = 294 | issue = 2 | pages = 218–228 | year = 2005 | pmid = 16014596 | pmc = }}</ref><ref>{{Cite web | author = David Gorski | title = The "decline effect": Is it a real decline or just science correcting itself? | url = http://www.sciencebasedmedicine.org/?p=8987/ | publisher = Science-based Medicine | year = 2010}}</ref>
A 2012 report by National Public Radio's show "On The Media"<ref>{{Cite web |author=Brooke Gladstone |title=The 'Decline Effect' and Scientific Truth |url=http://www.onthemedia.org/2012/jun/29/decline-effect-and-scientific-truth/ |publisher=NPR On The Media |year=2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120704061146/http://www.onthemedia.org/2012/jun/29/decline-effect-and-scientific-truth/ |archivedate=2012-07-04 |df= }}</ref> covered scientists who are exploring another option: that the act of observing the universe changes the universe, and that repeated measurement might actually be rendering earlier results invalid. In other words, antipsychotic drugs ''did'' work originally, but the more we measured their effectiveness, the more the laws governing those drugs changed so they ceased to be effective. Science fiction author [[Geoff Ryman]] explores this idea and its possible ramifications further in his 2012 short story <u>What We Found</u>,<ref>{{Cite web | author = Geoff Ryman | title = The Year's Best Science Fiction | url = https://www.amazon.com/The-Years-Best-Science-Fiction/dp/1250003547 | publisher = St. Martin's Griffin | year = 2012}}</ref> which won the [[Nebula Award for Best Novelette]] in 2012.<ref>{{Cite web | author = Mike Addelman | title = Ryman wins one of world’s top science fiction prizes | url = http://www.manchester.ac.uk/aboutus/news/display/?id=8297 | publisher = University of Manchester | year = 2012}}</ref>
==Contesting views==
Several commenters have contested Jonah Lehrer's view of the decline effect being a problematic side of the phenomenon, as presented in his ''New Yorker'' article. "The decline effect is troubling because it reminds us how difficult it is to prove anything. We like to pretend that our experiments define the truth for us. But that's often not the case. Just because an idea is true doesn't mean it can be proved. And just because an idea can be proved doesn't mean it's true. When the experiments are done, we still have to choose what to believe." <ref name="Lehrer" />
[[Steven Novella]] also challenges Lehrer's view of the decline effect, arguing that Lehrer is concentrating on new discoveries on the cutting edge of scientific research and applying the conclusions to all areas of science. Novella points out that most of the examples used by Lehrer come from medicine, psychology and ecology, scientific fields most influenced by a complex human aspect and that there is not much evidence of the decline effect in other areas of science, such as physics.<ref>{{Cite web | author = Steven Novella | title = The Decline Effect | url = http://theness.com/neurologicablog/?p=2580/ | publisher = Neurologicablog | year = 2010}}</ref>
Another scientist, [[Paul Zachary Myers]], is also contesting Lehrer's view on the decline effect being a surprising phenomenon in science, claiming that: "This isn't surprising at all. It's what we expect, and there are many very good reasons for the shift." <ref>{{Cite web |author=Paul Zachary Myers |title=Science is not dead |url=http://scienceblogs.com/pharyngula/2010/12/science_is_not_dead.php |publisher=Scienceblogs |year=2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110303224843/http://scienceblogs.com/pharyngula/2010/12/science_is_not_dead.php |archivedate=2011-03-03 |df= }}</ref>
Lehrer's statements about the difficulty of proving anything and publication bias find support from [[Jerry A. Coyne]]. Coyne holds that in the fields of genetics and evolutionary biology, almost no research is replicated and there is a premium motivation offered for publishing positive results of research studies. However, he also contests Lehrer's approach of applying conclusions on all fields of science, stating that in physics, chemistry or molecular biology, previous results are constantly repeated by others in order to progress in their own research.<ref>{{Cite web | author = Jerry Allen Coyne | title = Why Evolution is True | url = http://whyevolutionistrue.wordpress.com/2010/12/10/the-decline-effect-can-we-demonstrate-anything-in-science/ | publisher = Wordpress | year = 2010}}</ref>
==Criticism==
One concern that some <ref name="Horgan">{{Cite web | author = John Horgan | title = The truth we'll doubt: Does the decline effect mean that all science is "truthy"? | url = http://www.scientificamerican.com/blog/post.cfm?id=the-truth-well-doubt-does-the-decli-2010-12-13 | publisher = Scientific America | year = 2010}}</ref> have expressed is that Lehrer's article may further fuel people's skepticism about academic science. It was long believed that Lehrer's article originally hinted that academic science is not as rigid as people would like to believe. It is especially the article's ending that has upset many scientists and led to broad criticism of the article. Lehrer ends the article by saying: "Just because an idea is true doesn't mean it can be proved. And just because an idea can be proved doesn't mean it's true. When the experiments are done, we still have to choose what to believe." This has upset scientists in the scientific community. Many have written back to Lehrer and questioned his agenda. Some have characterized Lehrer's assertion as "absurd", while others claiming that Lehrer is trying to use publication bias as an excuse for not believing in anything.<ref name="Horgan" />
As an answer to the many comments Lehrer received upon publishing the article, Lehrer published a comment on his blog, The Frontal Cortex,<ref name="Lehrer2" /> where he denied that he was implicitly questioning science and scientific methods in any way. In the same blog comment, Lehrer stated that he was not questioning fundamental scientific theories such as the theory of evolution by natural selection and global warming by calling them "two of the most robust and widely tested theories of modern science".
A further clarification was published as a follow-up note in ''The New Yorker''.<ref name="Lehrer2" /> In this note, entitled "More Thoughts on the Decline Effect", Lehrer tries mainly to answer the critics by giving examples where scientific research has both failed and succeeded. As an example, Lehrer uses [[Richard Feynman]]'s [[commencement speech]] at Caltech in 1974 as a starting point. In his commencement speech, Feynman used [[Robert Millikan]]'s and [[Harvey Fletcher]]'s [[oil drop experiment]] to measure the charge of an electron to illustrate how selective reporting can bias scientific results. On the other hand, Feynman finds solace in the fact that other scientists will repeat other scientists' experiments and hence, the truth will win out in the end.
Lehrer once again uses the follow-up note to deny that his original intention was to support people denying well verified scientific theories such as natural selection and climate change. Instead, he wishes that "we'd spend more time considering the value of second-generation antipsychotics or the verity of the latest gene-association study". In the other parts of the follow-up note, Lehrer briefly discusses some of the creative feedback he has received in order to reduce publication bias. He does not give explicit support to any specific idea. The follow-up article ends with Lehrer once again stating that the decline effect is a problem in today's science, but that science will eventually find a tool to deal with the problem.

{{Infobox Academic Conference | logo = | history = 1989- | discipline = [[digital humanities]] | abbreviation = | publisher = [[Alliance of Digital Humanities Organizations|ADHO]] | country = International | frequency = annual }} The '''Digital Humanities conference''' is an [[academic conference]] for the field of [[digital humanities]]. It is hosted by [[Alliance of Digital Humanities Organizations]] and has been held annually since 1989.
==History== The first joint conference was held in 1989, at the [[University of Toronto]]—but that was the 16th annual meeting of [[ALLC]], and the ninth annual meeting of the [[Association for Computers and the Humanities|ACH]]-sponsored International Conference on Computers and the Humanities (ICCH).<ref>{{Cite web | title = Conference | work = ADHO | accessdate = 2012-02-12 | url = http://digitalhumanities.org/conference }}</ref>
The Chronicle of Higher Education has called the conference "highly competitive" but "worth the price of admission," praising its participants' focus on best practices, the intellectual community it has fostered, and the tendency of its organizers to sponsor attendance of early-career scholars (important given the relative expense of attending it, as compared to other academic conferences).<ref>{{cite web | last1 = Pannapacker | first1 = William | title = 'Big Tent Digital Humanities,' a View From the Edge, Part 1 | url = http://chronicle.com/article/Big-Tent-Digital-Humanities/128434 | website = Chronicle of Higher Education | publisher = Chronicle of Higher Education | accessdate = 23 October 2015}} </ref>
An analysis of the Digital Humanities conference abstracts between 2004 and 2014<ref>{{cite web|last1=Eichmann|first1=Nickoal|last2=Weingart|first2=Scott|title=What’s Under the Big Tent? A Study of ADHO Conference Abstracts, 2004-2014|url=http://figshare.com/articles/What_s_under_the_Big_Tent_A_study_of_ADHO_Conference_Abstracts_2004_2014/1461760|website=figshare|accessdate=23 October 2015}}</ref> highlights some trends evident in the evolution of the conference (such as the increasing rate of new authors entering the field, and the continuing disproportional predominance of authors from North America represented in the abstracts). An extended study (2000-2015) offer a feminist and critical engagement of Digital Humanities conferences with solutions for a more inclusive culture.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Eichmann-Kalwara|first=Nickoal|last2=Jorgensen|first2=Jeana|last3=Weingart|first3=Scott|date=2016-03-21|title=Representation at Digital Humanities Conferences (2000-2015) [pre-print]|url=https://figshare.com/articles/Representation_at_Digital_Humanities_Conferences_2000_2015_/3120610/1|doi=10.6084/m9.figshare.3120610.v1}}</ref> Scott Weingart has also published detailed analyses of submissions to Digital Humanities 2013, 2014, 2015, and 2016 on his blog.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Weingart|first1=Scott|title=dhconf - the scottbot irregular|url=http://www.scottbot.net/HIAL/?tag=dhconf|website=the scottbot irregular|publisher=Scott Weingart|accessdate=23 October 2015}}</ref>

{{Use dmy dates|date=November 2011}} The '''ecological urbanism''' project draws from ecology to inspire an urbanism that is more socially inclusive and sensitive to the environment, as well as less ideologically driven, than [[green urbanism]] or [[Sustainable Urbanism|sustainable urbanism]]. In many ways, ecological urbanism is an evolution of, and a critique of, [[Landscape urbanism|Landscape Urbanism]] arguing for a more holistic approach to the design and management of cities. The term appeared first in 1998 as "EcoUrbanism" in a book by Architect and Planner Miguel Ruano,<ref>Eco-Urbanism: Sustainable Human Settlements, 60 Case Studies – Gustavo Gili, 1998 - 192 pages | http://www.abebooks.com/9788425217234/Eco-Urbanism-Sustainable-Human-Settlements-Case-8425217237/plp</ref> who defined it as "the development of multi-dimensional sustainable human communities within harmonious and balanced built environments". The term was used later in April 2003 at a conference at the University of Oregon,<ref>http://pages.uoregon.edu/hopes/oldhopes/conf03/emailposter.pdf</ref> and again in 2006 in a paper by Jeffrey Hou.<ref>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=HOJPAAAAMAAJ&q=ecological+urbanism#search_anchor |title=Proceedings of the ... ACSA Annual ... – Association of Collegiate Schools of Architecture – Google Books |publisher=Google Books |accessdate=10 November 2011}}</ref> The phrase was used by [[Mohsen Mostafavi]] in 2007 in ''Intervention Architecture''<ref name="Intervention architecture"/> and in a lecture at the [[Canadian Centre for Architecture]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cca.qc.ca/en/education-events/247-sustainable |title=Sustainable? | Canadian Centre for Architecture |publisher=CCA |date=17 June 2007 |accessdate=10 November 2011}}</ref> ecological urbanism as a project was largely started at [[Harvard University Graduate School of Design]], with a conference, and exhibition, and book.<ref name="Ecological Urbanism Harvard"/>
Arguing for a "new ethics and aesthetics of the urban," the 656-page ''Ecological Urbanism'' book, edited by Mohsen Mostafavi with Gareth Doherty, was published in May 2010 by Lars Müller Publishers ({{ISBN|978-3-03778-189-0}}).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.lars-mueller-publishers.com/en/catalogue-architecture |title=Architecture – Lars Müller Publishers |publisher=Lars-mueller-publishers.com |date=14 July 1938 |accessdate=10 November 2011}}</ref> The book follows the conference,<ref name="conference"/> and exhibition, held at the GSD in 2009.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.boston.com/ae/theater_arts/articles/2009/04/12/exhibit_provides_sense_of_the_future/ | work=The Boston Globe | first=Robert | last=Campbell | title=Exhibit provides sense of the future | date=12 April 2009}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://ecologicalurbanism.gsd.harvard.edu/exhibition.php |title=Exhibition on Ecological Urbanism – Harvard Graduate School of Design |publisher=Ecologicalurbanism.gsd.harvard.edu |date=17 May 2009 |accessdate=10 November 2011}}</ref><ref>[http://www.gsd.harvard.edu/events/exhibitions/Ecological%20Urbanism/eco_urban_final.htm ] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100708031955/http://www.gsd.harvard.edu/events/exhibitions/Ecological%20Urbanism/eco_urban_final.htm |date=8 July 2010 }}</ref> The book has a long list of contributors, including [[Rem Koolhaas]], [[Homi K. Bhabha]], [[Mitchell Joachim]], [[Andrea Branzi]], and about 130 others. A blog during the conference is part of the book.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://gsd-ecologicalurbanism.blogspot.com/ |title=GSD:ecologicalurbanism |publisher=Gsd-ecologicalurbanism.blogspot.com |accessdate=10 November 2011}}</ref> According to [http://www.architecturetoday.co.uk/ ''Architecture Today''], the book is "one of the few books that recognises and articulates how, if this systems-based approach is to be successful, it needs to design, integrate and express complex systems and social processes in ways that are fundamentally humane."<ref name="AT Review"/> The book has been reviewed and cited in many publications, including [''Metropolis Magazine''],<ref name="Metropolis review"/> [http://www.info-jola.de/ ''The Journal of Landscape Architecture''],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.jola-lab.eu/www/issues.html |title=JoLA | Issue 11 | Spring 2011 |publisher=Jola-lab.eu |accessdate=10 November 2011}}</ref> and [http://www.citiesthemagazine.com/ Cities magazine].<ref>{{cite web|author=Cities |url=http://vimeo.com/16500456 |title=Ecological Urbanism – Book Review On Vimeo |publisher=Vimeo.com |accessdate=10 November 2011}}</ref> Events and discussions on the book have been held at the 2010 Venice Biennale,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.abitare.it/biennale-to-the-people/anticipate/ |title=Anticipate? | Abitare |publisher=Abitare.it |accessdate=10 November 2011}}</ref> the [[Storefront for Art and Architecture]] in New York, and at the Van Alen Institute in New York.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.vanalen.org/projects/events/EcologicalExchange |title=Van Alen Institute – Events – Ecological Urbanism and Green Gone Wrong: An Exchange |publisher=Vanalen.org |accessdate=10 November 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111129110856/http://www.vanalen.org/projects/events/EcologicalExchange |archivedate=29 November 2011 |df=dmy }}</ref>
In his introduction to the ''Ecological Urbanism'', "Why Ecological Urbanism? Why Now?", extracted in [https://www.topos.de/ ''Topos: The International Review of Landscape Architecture and Urban Design''], Mostafavi asks: "Increased numbers of people and cities go hand in hand with a greater exploitation of the world’s limited resources. Every year, more cities are feeling the devastating impacts of this situation. What are we to do? What means do we have as designers to address this challenging reality?<ref>https://www.topos.de/Previous-issue/detail-991.html</ref>
Jeb Brugmann in his book ''Welcome to the Urban Revolution: How Cities Are Changing the World'' (Bloomsbury Press, 2009) says we need to become "masters of a stable, just, and ecological urbanism." For Brugmann, "The first step towards ecological urbanism is increasing the energy and nutrient productivity within the city, but the only way to move sufficiently from extractive mode to a sustainable productive mode is to think, design, and develop at the scale of the City."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.policyinnovations.org/ideas/innovations/data/000176 |title=Welcome to the Urban Revolution |publisher=Policyinnovations.org |date=28 October 2010 |accessdate=10 November 2011}}</ref>
There have been a number of recent conferences and lectures on the project of ecological urbanism, including: The New Aesthetics and Ecological Urbanism at Peking University in October 2010,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.alicerawsthorn.com/talks_debates.php |title=Alice Rawsthorn |publisher=Alice Rawsthorn |accessdate=10 November 2011}}</ref> New Zealand Institute of Landscape Architects Spring Lecture Series: Ecological Urbanism: A Prospectus for the Super City, in October 2010.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dinz.org.nz/Events/2010/October/46049 |title=Events – NZILA Spring Lecture Series: Ecological Urbanism – a prospectus for the super city |publisher=DINZ |date=1 October 2010 |accessdate=10 November 2011}}</ref> The University of Washington’s urban initiative included a seminar on Now Urbanism<ref>{{cite web|author=21Oct10 |url=http://sawyerseminaratuw.wordpress.com/2010/10/21/ecological-urbanism-gradseminar/ |title=Ecological Urbanism [gradseminar] « Now Urbanism |publisher=Sawyerseminaratuw.wordpress.com |accessdate=10 November 2011}}</ref> and talks "on Ecological Urbanism, Ecological Design for Healthy Cities, Networked Urbanism, and America’s War on Immigrants.”<ref>{{cite web|last=Roth |first=Rick |url=http://depts.washington.edu/geog/2010/10/city-making-in-the-21st-century-and-beyond/ |title=City Making In The 21st century and Beyond | Department of Geography |publisher=Depts.washington.edu |date=4 October 2010 |accessdate=10 November 2011}}</ref> Eco-Urbanism: towards sustainable city living, was hosted by Nottingham University at the Shanghai Expo in August 2010.<ref>http://www.nottingham.ac.uk/.../eco-urbanismprogramme.doc</ref>
In addition to courses at the GSD in 2008<ref>http://www.gsd.harvard.edu/cgi-bin/courses/details.cgi?section_id=10874&term=f2008</ref> and 2011,<ref>http://www.gsd.harvard.edu/cgi-bin/courses/details.cgi?section_id=12383&term=s2011</ref> there have been courses on ecological urbanism at the Bergen School of Architecture,<ref name="BAS Course"/> Oslo School of Architecture and Design,<ref name="Univ Oslo Course"/> and Yale University.<ref name="YSOA Course"/> It is on numerous course syllabi, including Advanced Design Theories 2010 at Florida International University.<ref>[http://www2.fiu.edu/~readg/Courses/GradTheory/GradTheorySyllabus2010.htm ]{{dead link|date=November 2011}}</ref> Arizona State University expanded on the subject with a lecture by Charles Anderson, ASLA.<ref>[[Charles Morris Anderson]]</ref> Anderson stated that "ecology is concerned with the relationships between all organisms and the environment. Together and coupled with aesthetic and expressionist design principles, they form the foundation for urban design."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://design.asu.edu/events/lectures_archive.php}}</ref>
==Criticism of ecological urbanism== Ecological urbanism has been criticized as an idea that is loosely defined from a set of flashy projects. These are expensive schemes with a commercial and esthetic purpose that satisfy a local or regional ambition to invest in ecology or sustainability without posing a more globally applicable approach. A true merger of landscape architecture with the field of Urban Ecology lacks. From this criticism Frederick Steiner introduced landscape ecological urbanism as an approach that can include the field of urban ecology and Wybe Kuitert has shown how such integrative planning and management of the city should rely on analysis.<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Steiner | first1 = F. R. | year = 2011 | title = Landscape Ecological Urbanism: Origins and Trajectories | url = | journal = Landscape and Urban Planning | volume = 100 | issue = | pages = 333–337 | doi=10.1016/j.landurbplan.2011.01.020}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Kuitert | first1 = Wybe | year = 2013 | title = Urban landscape systems understood by geo-history map overlay | doi = 10.1080/18626033.2013.798929 | journal = Journal of Landscape Architecture | volume = 8 | issue = 1| pages = 54–63 }}</ref> Discerning the potential quality of wild nature in the city is a first step to see how new urban ecology might be developed. Potential vegetation maps for a city are the tool to this end.<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Kuitert | first1 = | year = 2013 | title = The Nature of Urban Seoul: Potential Vegetation Derived from the Soil Map | doi = 10.1080/12265934.2013.766505 | journal = International Journal of Urban Sciences | volume = 17 | issue = 1| pages = 95–108 }}</ref>
Ecological Urbanism is explained as a successor to Landscape Urbanism without the difference between the two approaches, and the terms used in the new approach, being defined. Jason King sees it as an inadequately explained addition to a list of 61 other 'Fill-in-the-blank Urbanisms'.<ref>http://landscapeandurbanism.blogspot.co.uk/2010/05/ecological-urbanism-introduction-part-2.html</ref> [[Tom Turner]] welcomes landscape and ecological urbanism as 'the most significant contributions to landscape design theory since the landscape architecture profession was launched in the mid-nineteenth century' but is 'unpersuaded by the change of name' <ref>http://www.gardenvisit.com/blog/2014/01/02/landscape-ecological-urbanism/</ref>
